history.content:
1. Lab assist (and go above and beyond when lab assisting) for 1-2 semesters.

2. Apply to be a tutor, do for 1-2 semesters.

3. TA!

-------------

I'd like to add 3 ways that can boost your chances of becoming a TA:

  1. Set up a meeting directly with the professor teaching the course and explain to them in person why you are a qualified candidate. (This is really important)
  2. Become an avid participant in the class while you are a student; make yourself known (in a positive way) among the staff while you are a student. Best way imo is through piazza.
  3. Make friends with an influential TA and show them how much you care about the class, and kindly ask them to refer you to the professor.

The reality about TA hiring is that it is often (for the better or worse) dependent on the connections you have. You don't necessarily always have to go through lab assisting and tutoring to become a TA; in rare cases if you excel at knowing the right people and show yourself as a motivated, qualified candidate, you can become a TA. Be patient, it took me several tries before it worked. Once you become a TA it is much easier applying for other courses in the future. The hard part is getting in, I think.

---------

Directly becoming a uGSI without serving in course staff is certainly possible, but rare.

Having experience as lab assistants, tutors, or readers (for the latter, especially for more problem-set heavy courses like 70 or 170 where they hire more readers and readers also interact with students more) certainly helps, especially for that class in particular and especially if you stand out when doing so. (I suppose you can think of it as seeking a promotion.) At least in the past, a semester as part of the course staff was usually enough to identify who would be a good TA.

I'll add something not mentioned previously, which is that it's most easy to become a first-time TA (especially without course staff experience) during the summer, because many regular TAs / stronger candidates are doing internships instead, so the labor supply is much smaller. (Of course, you might prefer an internship as well; it works both ways.) My first time as a TA was during the summer for CS70, and all of the TAs (except for the head TA) were first-time TAs. (Two were grad students, but the rest were undergrads, and I don't think any of the others besides myself had been a reader for CS70 previously.)

And, of course, grades matter. (I recall in one instance where an A was a hard cutoff and the instructor didn't offer interviews to anyone below that.) Probably less if you had course staff experience with the class and/or TA experience in a different class.

1. Lab assist (and go above and beyond when lab assisting) for 1-2 semesters.

2. Apply to be a tutor, do for 1-2 semesters.

3. TA!

-------------

I'd like to add 3 ways that can boost your chances of becoming a TA:

  1. Set up a meeting directly with the professor teaching the course and explain to them in person why you are a qualified candidate. (This is really important)
  2. Become an avid participant in the class while you are a student; make yourself known (in a positive way) among the staff while you are a student. Best way imo is through piazza.
  3. Make friends with an influential TA and show them how much you care about the class, and kindly ask them to refer you to the professor.

The reality about TA hiring is that it is often (for the better or worse) dependent on the connections you have. You don't necessarily always have to go through lab assisting and tutoring to become a TA; in rare cases if you excel at knowing the right people and show yourself as a motivated, qualified candidate, you can become a TA. Be patient, it took me several tries before it worked. Once you become a TA it is much easier applying for other courses in the future. The hard part is getting in, I think.

1. Lab assist (and go above and beyond when lab assisting) for 1-2 semesters.

2. Apply to be a tutor, do for 1-2 semesters.

3. TA!
Im current a freshman. I definitely want to TA either 61A or some similar class as soon as possible. What are the steps to becoming a TA? I want to know so that I can make the necessary decisions.
history.subject: How does one become a TA?
